Highly organized, able to effectively coordinate tasks to accomplish projects despite competing priorities while staying calm under pressure.   Proficient in systems such as Trackwise, SAP, Veeva, Salesforce and MS Office.  Excellent technical and communication skills.  Analytical, detail-orientated, dependable and conscientious worker.
headline: Patient Access Representative

message.text:
Why oh why do we put things off until the very last minute? Asking for a friend (who may or may not be wearing yesterday's clothes because laundry folding is SO next week's problem) 🤦🏼‍♀️

Turns out, everyone does it – even those neurotypical brains. But for our sparkly ADHD brains?!? Well, procrastination can be a whole other beast!

The white coats tell us that:

🧠 ADHD brains procrastinate more frequently (I know! Cue the shock and awe!!!)

🧠 ADHD brains pay the price of procrastination more often (whomp, whomp)

So all that ⬆️ is about as shocking as finding out your couch doesn't actually double as a trampoline.  But you know that ACTUALLY kind of revelatory thing those smarty-pants have found?

Procrastination is actually not about time management at all!!!!  It's about EMOTION regulation!

Yup! You read that right!

We procrastinate because we start feeling pesky feelings like:

🧠 Boredom
🧠 Frustration
🧠 Confusion
🧠 Disinterest
🧠 Shame

It's not a laziness thing. It's not a time management thing.  It's not always even a motivation thing.  Often it's an EMOTION thing!

Any other master procrastinators out there?🙋🏼‍♀️ What are your best tips for getting things done (eventually)? Together we can bust through this emotional wall and get stuff done!

ingestedContentSummary.description: Explore the connection between ADHD and passive suicidal ideation. Learn how therapy, coping mechanisms, and support networks help manage challenges, providing a path forward.
ingestedContentSummary.fullText: Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder, commonly known as ADHD, is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder that is primarily characterized by persistent patterns of inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity. These symptoms, however, can present differently from one person to another, making ADHD a highly individualized condition. Some individuals may struggle more with inattention, having difficulty focusing, organizing, and completing tasks, while others may primarily exhibit hyperactivity and impulsivity, such as fidgeting, restlessness, and making hasty actions without thinking. Therefore, the manifestation and severity of ADHD symptoms can vary widely among individuals, underscoring the need for personalized approaches in managing and treating this condition. Symptoms of Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) encompass a wide variety of behavioral issues. These include difficulty in maintaining focus or concentration, being easily and frequently distracted by irrelevant stimuli, making hasty decisions without thoughtful consideration, and a general feeling of restlessness. Not only are these symptoms challenging on their own, but they can also significantly impact an individual's daily life. This can manifest in various ways, such as hindering educational performance and leading to students struggling to keep up with their peers. In a work environment, these symptoms can reduce productivity, as tasks may take longer to complete or mistakes may occur more frequently. Furthermore, these behavioral issues may strain relationships, as those close to the individual may find it difficult to understand and cope with their behavior. Passive suicidal ideation is a complex and distressing psychological state where an individual experiences persistent thoughts about death or harbors a desire for their life to end, but without taking any active steps towards planning or attempting suicide. This is a manifestation of deep psychological distress and often indicates a profound lack of motivation to continue living. It's a silent struggle, often hidden from view, that can greatly affect an individual's daily life, relationships, and overall mental well-being. It's a cry for help and a sign that immediate professional help should be sought to address the underlying issues and provide the necessary support and treatment. The distinction between passive and active suicidal ideation is primarily situated in the sphere of intention and the presence or absence of a concrete plan. Active suicidal ideation is characterized by the presence of specific plans or attempts to terminate one's life. This may involve identifying a method, setting a time, and making arrangements for the act. On the other hand, passive suicidal ideation involves thoughts and feelings about not wanting to continue living, but these thoughts are not accompanied by the immediate intention to take action. The individual might have a general desire to die or wish that they could go to sleep and never wake up, but they have not made any specific plans to carry out suicide. Despite the lack of immediate danger, passive suicidal ideation is still a serious concern that requires professional attention. Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD), a chronic condition marked by persistent inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity, can significantly contribute to feelings of passive suicidal ideation in a multitude of ways. One of these ways is through the emotional dysregulation commonly associated with ADHD. This emotional dysregulation can manifest as intense, uncontrollable feelings of sadness, anger, or frustration. These emotional challenges, combined with the daily life challenges that individuals with ADHD often face, such as maintaining relationships, holding down a job, or staying organized, can lead to feelings of frustration and hopelessness. This is because these tasks, which may seem commonplace for most people, can seem monumental and insurmountable for those with ADHD. Consequently, the combined effects of emotional regulation difficulties and daily life challenges often lead to a sense of hopelessness and despair. It is this very sense of despair and hopelessness that can, in turn, potentially result in passive suicidal thoughts. This is a crucial aspect that needs further exploration and understanding among healthcare professionals, caregivers, and the affected individuals themselves. Therapy, in its various forms, can play a pivotal role in managing the symptoms and effects of both Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) and passive suicidal ideation. Cognitive-behavioral therapy, commonly known as CBT , is one such form of therapy. CBT helps individuals develop effective coping strategies to manage the day-to-day challenges brought on by their symptoms. It also provides a safe space for individuals to explore the underlying distress and discomfort that often accompanies these conditions. Another form of therapy that is particularly effective is Dialectical Behavior Therapy or DBT. DBT places a particular emphasis on emotional regulation and mindfulness. These aspects help individuals navigate the daily challenges and emotional fluctuations that are often part and parcel of living with ADHD and passive suicidal ideation. Through these therapeutic approaches, individuals can gain a better understanding of their condition and learn tools and techniques to manage their symptoms more effectively. Additionally, the introduction of support groups and counseling sessions can be an invaluable resource. These platforms provide a safe and supportive environment that encourages open communication. This allows individuals to share their unique experiences and challenges, which can lead to a sense of solidarity and understanding. Moreover, giving and receiving encouragement from peers who are going through similar struggles can significantly enhance feelings of resilience and motivation. Furthermore, these sessions can be a platform for exploring various coping mechanisms. Through professional guidance and peer input, individuals can discover and implement strategies that are most effective for their specific needs and circumstances. In managing both conditions of passive suicidal ideation and ADHD-related challenges, the role of self-care and mindfulness practices cannot be understated. These practices encompass a variety of techniques that promote physical and mental health, allowing individuals to better manage their symptoms and improve their overall well-being. Specifically, techniques such as meditation and breathing exercises can be particularly effective. Meditation is a practice where an individual uses a technique – such as mindfulness, or focusing their mind on a particular object, thought, or activity – to train attention and awareness, and achieve a mentally clear and emotionally calm and stable state. In parallel, breathing exercises can help to reduce stress and improve emotional regulation, which can be particularly beneficial for those struggling with these conditions. Furthermore, maintaining a balanced lifestyle, which involves regular physical activity, a nutritious diet, and adequate sleep, can significantly reduce stress levels and improve emotional regulation. By implementing these strategies, individuals can develop healthier coping mechanisms and manage the challenges associated with passive suicidal ideation and ADHD more effectively.
ingestedContentSummary.title: Passive Suicidal Ideation ADHD: Understanding the Connection — Meridian Counseling

message.text:
The complex intersections between passive suicidal ideation and ADHD, or Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder, can often be difficult to comprehend, but gaining an understanding of this intricate relationship is of vital importance. Both conditions present their unique challenges and can significantly impact the quality of life of those affected. As such, understanding how these two conditions can be intertwined is an essential first step towards effectively managing them. This knowledge not only helps individuals to navigate through the complex challenges associated with each condition but also provides a solid foundation for establishing effective treatments and strategies for coping.

Neurodiversity Celebration does not have to mean
"let's be positive about everything" 🧠🌈

I do not recognise my AuDHD as a superpower because simply it isn't. I identify as a disabled person because being autistic and ADHD can be disabling. That doesn't mean I think negatively about being an AuDHDer, it just means l'm neutral.

Disability and neurodivergence are not "negative" terms. They also do not have to be "superpowers." Instead they can be recognised as neutral concepts.

For me, talking about my disability as a "superpower" feels invalidating. It invalidates the daily struggles I have. When people tell me l have a "superpower" it causes harm. It makes me feel like I can't request accommodations or support or advocate for my different needs, because it's supposed to be a "superpower."

When people label me as having a "superpower" it forces me to only talk about the positive, good aspects of being neurodivergent.

It then feels wrong to talk about the difficult, disabling aspects, because it's a "superpower." Who would complain about having a superpower?

When people tell me I have a "superpower" it makes me feel like a child again. It's the type of thing people said to me growing up. It feels patronising.

When I'm told I have a "superpower" I feel like my voice is ignored immediately. It feels like if I acknowledge my struggles l'll just be told to try harder, like l've been told over and over before diagnosis I don't want to go back there.

I understand that people want to make me feel positive about being disabled. But I can still be disabled by my neurotype and still feel accepting of it. I fully appreciate and accept the way my brain works.

I love my brain! 🧠🌈

#Neurodiversity #NeurodiversityCelebrationWeek #Neurodivergent #NeurodivergentWomen #AutisticWomen #ADHDWomen #AuDHD #Neurodivergence #NeurodiversityCelebration #DisabilityPride

"The specific purpose of the inquiry is to understand how the discredited concept of “parental alienation” has been advanced into custody proceedings worldwide and how it is undermining the welfare and safety of children. To those unaware of this concept or the behaviour of family courts what you will read below may seem absurd, but it is through this absurdity that the family court is able to avoid greater public scrutiny – people unexposed to the system simply wouldn’t believe that it could function with such irrationality and brutality. It is incredibly positive that the UN is now paying serious attention to what has become one of the great moral and ethical failures of recent decades.

This should not be considered a niche issue. It is important for both political science and international relations for three reasons: Firstly, how societies treat women and children is the true reflection of their social health - and the behaviour of justice systems provides the legal framework to these values. Secondly, one of the central pillars of our current political instability is men’s inability to emotionally cope with the advancement of women, and their attempt to reassert their “natural authority” – a desire to dominate individuals, groups, nations, or land is all driven by the same psychological impulse. And thirdly, the family court provides a stark lesson in how institutions can easily become captured by bad ideas, and how difficult it can be to weed them out when many actors within and around institutions are professionally – and financially – invested in these ideas." - Grant Wyeth

Friendly reminder that therapists are people too. 

I am seeing more and more stories about clients recording therapy sessions without the therapist’s consent or knowledge, for various reasons. It’s a whole TikTok trend. 

Just because something is technically legal (in many states at least, in others it’s not and I have no idea outside the US), doesn’t mean it’s ethical or generally courteous. 

Should therapists be expected to hold clinically sound and ethical sessions, regardless of who is or isn’t watching? Yeah, of course. 

But would you want to be recorded at work without your knowledge? Probably not. 

Therapists deserve to have informed consent too. 


#recordingtherapysessions #informedconsent #privatepractice

I have noticed a lot of conversation with my friends here around the late identification of autism in girls. Why is this happening? In my opinion, it’s a lack of awareness and education and also the DM diagnostic criteria needs updating. I am not a qualified doctor, so will leave the second advocacy gauntlet to those who carry that accolade, whilst cheering loudly from the sidelines offering any support that could be useful. I thought this graphic did a great job to start a conversation on how it presents in young people who identify as girls. I certainly exhibited a large amount of these. What do you think, is there anything you would add here? 

#autism #actuallyautistic #AuADHD #earlydetectionsaveslives #earlydiagnosis

Many mental health conditions affect more women than men or affect women in different ways from men. Too often in our society, people write these issues off as “just hormones” or as “dramatic.” We’re here to remind you that mental health is real and you deserve to get the help you need.

Visit bit.ly/371Mfgn to find care near you.
